msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to Harry, , Oct 4th. 1834

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

revisionDesc.change: Created file for letter, encoded letter

div.p:
It is very
dispiriting to us, what must it
be to you to find that you do
not mend - down at Richmond
Still we hope on - tomorrows
post!

No answer from Spring
Rice - perhaps this is a good
augury - as he says nothing
he may be doing something
But it is possible that he said
nothing to Captain Beaufort
but that he had had a letter
from Miss E. - How could
he avail saying more to such
a man - a father such as he
is too and at such a time -
I am assured ossification of the
heart come on in certain situa
tions situations inevitably -

I enclose the two letters of
Capt. Captain
Halls which you forwarded
to me - I think you will
like to read a great part of them
though the first pages may
tire you - Read my answer
or not my dear just as you
indeed you must read the lage page because it concerns you
please - and forward it as di
=rected -- whenever
Captn. Captain Halls
next letter comes pray open &
read
as much as you like to read.

I am much obliged to Lestock
for having paid my balance
£102.7.9 to G J Hinds and Houses
Banks & this be his rest in fall
for the same - I have determined
to postpone building till Spring
and till I see the school actually
set a going - The corner plot I
meant is Sodens - at the corner
of the road turning up to the Church
- Your mother will leave me
a perfect plan & I can use it
whenever I please - Whenever
I do build I will engage a good
carpenter of the name of Green
who is sober all the week - till Sa
turday night - I wish I could
get one perfectly sober - but I fear
that must come next generation
after the diffusion of knowledge
shall I say? - or after the infusion
of resolution & self control which is quite ano
ther another part of education - not always
comprehended under that misused
word- We have new commission
ers of public instruction going
about and coming here I believe
next week - But who or what
I can't say Ma'am any anymore
than Capedy - Capedy is really
a wonderful instance of the power
of late improvement tale in life -
Do you know he has learned not

to put the chairs against the
Dining Hall
closed door in consequence of my
once seriously explaining how
inconvenient it was to us - And
moreover he has cured himself
of saying Mr Pacock and now says
Mr Peacock most genteelly - And
this only after once asking -

Honora and my mother
have given you an account of
all the terrible events of poor Mrs
Stewart death and the 8 deaths
by cholera - I wish Miss Crampton
had told me what course was
pursued with her father when
he had the cholera.

Mr. Stewart is very amiable
and interesting from his
perfectly unaffected feeling
and goodness - I wish after
he has been some time away
for his own sake he may
come back as he says he will
and settle here - Though he
is very good he is not too good
- he is of the really charitable &
hopeful sort - the truly conciliatory
& liberal -

Mr. Bell was here yesterday & tells
me he has completed my little job
at Trim Vicarage & I hope it will
be approved. .-
The looking glass with the drawing
of the building on it is not at all

confused. I thought it must be be-
fore before I saw it - but on the contrary
it has a very good clear effect
- It is placed over the table at
which you used to draw be-
tween between the middle piers opposite
the bay window - (library
understood).

I hope you may be able to get
in Capn. Halls
pavie=ing paving one-
self - But fear I have made a
mistake about that correction
coming just in time -

Pray tell me whether you
think the following sentence
is or is not good English
"I will bring the accounts
to you when I come"
The doubt is as to the
propriety of bring.

postscript.p:
I do not know whether the
Hans 27 St. James Street to
whom
Captn. Captain Hall desires me to
send letters for him is an Esquire
or keeper of a coffee house - You will
be so kind to finish my direction as the case
may be
